critique: This executive order establishes a commission for the International Year of the Child. It focuses on children's well-being, health, education, and legal rights. There's no direct indication of a liberal or conservative tilt, so it's relatively centrist. It doesn't directly address immigration. It expands executive power slightly by creating a commission, but it's temporary and focused on a specific issue. It involves federal coordination but doesn't necessarily shift power dramatically from state to federal. It emphasizes the well-being of children, which could be seen as a social issue, but it doesn't strongly promote diversity or conformity. It doesn't directly regulate the economy. It seems to be a balanced approach to children's issues.
